image.altText: Woman with fair hair and man with grey hair stand together in formal clothes.

props.synopsis: Senator Linda Reynolds's lawyer tries to eviscerate Brittany Higgins's defamation defence by painting her as a deliberate liar who tried to ruin her former boss's career and bring down the Morrison government.

title.children: Linda Reynolds's lawyer attacks 'arrogant' Brittany Higgins for trivialising senator's hurt from the 'sanctity of France'

image.altText: A smirking man wearing a brown shirt takes a selfie shot.

props.synopsis: A seven-year-old who was allegedly smothered, choked and sexually assaulted by a man who broke into her home in the Perth suburb of Ellenbrook, told police she was not sure if it was a "nightmare or real".

title.children: Little girl allegedly sexually assaulted in bedroom told police she wasn't sure if it was a nightmare

image.altText: A close up side shot of a middle-aged man with brown hair.

props.synopsis: A snap road safety summit is held by the state government in Perth as parents like Daniel Campo and Carolyn Herring call for a new approach to reduce road deaths.

title.children: Heartbroken parents say change desperately needed as road toll climbs across 'terrible first half of the year'

image.altText: hands typing on a computer keyboard.

props.synopsis: A man charged with possessing child exploitation material is confirmed to be the principal of a private school in Perth's western suburbs.

title.children: Perth school principal charged with child exploitation offence, sacked from role

image.altText: A woman with long black hair wearing an olive shirt looks at the camera

props.synopsis: A teenager who died while locked up in youth detention would still be alive if he wasn't removed from a specialised care program, the organisation who ran it says.

title.children: Boy who died in WA's troubled youth detention system may be alive if he'd stayed in specialised care, organisation says

image.altText: an aerial view of a lithium ore crushing facility

props.synopsis: Slowing EV sales and a flood of new supply have seen the price of lithium fall off a cliff, but Australian miners are confident in a lithium-fuelled future.

title.children: Australian miners in damage control as the mineral once hailed to spark the next boom is in market freefall

props.synopsis: Country firefighters say modern house fires are hotter, longer and more intense than those in the past, and increasingly caused by batteries in devices like e-scooters and laptops.

title.children: Firefighters face growing danger as lithium-ion batteries spark more severe blazes

image.altText: A wide shot of the District Court in Perth with two men walking towards its doors.

props.synopsis: A juror in a WA rape trial will have to pay nearly $15,000 for discussing the case with a friend, who went on to contact the alleged victim.

title.children: Juror fined for revealing details of rape trial to friend, who went on to stalk alleged victim

image.altText: Alan Kohler, dressed in a dark suit with a light patterned tie, is superimposed in front of Flinders St Station

props.synopsis:
Houses in Adelaide and Perth are now more expensive than in Melbourne after another month of divergence in Aussie housing.

But as Alan Kohler explains, Sydney is still the most expensive place in the country to buy a house.

title.children: Adelaide, Perth houses cost more than Melbourne

image.altText: Brisbane airport with air traffic control in background.

props.synopsis: A safety investigation finds the Brisbane air traffic controller was fatigued after working a string of night shifts, prompting changes to staffing and training.

title.children: Air traffic controller found asleep under blanket while on the job

image.altText: Sailing ship with broken mast and rigging alongside wharf.

props.synopsis: The future of a beloved tall ship involved in a crash at Fremantle Port is being investigated as two injured crew members are discharged from hospital but remain "very shaken up".

title.children: 'Good news' emerges for Leeuwin sailing ship damaged in port crash as injured crew members recover

image.altText: A young man in a tropical shirt with

props.synopsis: Six months after he was kidnapped into Gaza with a grisly injury, 23-year-old Hersh Goldberg-Polin stunned everyone by appearing alive in a hostage video. His sudden death at the weekend has galvanised a nation.

title.children: Hersh was a symbol of hope for Israelis. His death has turned him into a symbol of rage against Netanyahu

image.altText: Skyscapers make up a very business end of town skyline

props.synopsis: As Australian mortgage holders wait for relief, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand cuts rates and green shoots emerge in the housing market.

title.children: 'The first cut is the deepest': NZ's central bank has cut rates and economists are singing a different tune

image.altText: James Turner crouches with an Australian flag next to a screen showing his world record time

props.synopsis: James Turner claims 400m T36 gold in style, breaking the world record on day six of the Paralympic Games in Paris. Follow the action in our live blog.

title.children: James Turner claims Paralympics gold and world record in 400m T36

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Tim Hodge's beautiful message to children fighting disabilities
Jaryd Clifford 'gutted' after being narrowly denied a medal

image.altText: Woman with tiger.

props.synopsis: An animal rescue organisation wants interactions between tigers and their handlers limited, as investigations continue into the mauling of an experienced worker at the Queensland theme park.

title.children: Dreamworld tiger attack prompts call for law change to protect animals and handlers

image.altText: Tim Bowden image

props.synopsis: Bowden discovered journalism as a teenager, sneaking into the back row of the theatre in 1950s Hobart to watch Cinesound newsreels, long before television was invented.

title.children: Former ABC broadcaster and author Tim Bowden dies, aged 87

image.altText: A man stands beside the rootball of a tree with a diameter twice the height of him

props.synopsis: Tasmanians are working to repair damage from floods and high winds that hit the state over the past week, but the window of calm weather may be small with a new front expected to develop on Wednesday.

title.children: Reprieve in wild weather for Tasmania, as state works to repair damage from flooding and high winds

image.altText: A person wearing a keffiyeh holds their fingers up in a peace sign, a Palestinian flag is in the background.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of Palestinian people apply for permanent protection as their tourist visas expire. Meanwhile the Coalition heaps pressure on the government after remarks made by ASIO boss Mike Burgess.

title.children: With expiring tourist visas, Palestinian people are applying for permanent protection in Australia

image.altText: Protesters walk along a street holding a massive sign that says 'CFMEU. Here to stay'.

props.synopsis: The former national president of the CFMEU launches a legal challenge to laws that force the construction union to accept an administrator, after allegations of criminal consorting, corruption and thuggery.

title.children: Former CFMEU heads launch high court challenge over forced administration

image.altText: A child's hands plays with toys on wooden table

props.synopsis: A new workforce report has outlined the urgent need for more than 20,000 qualified early childhood education professionals across Australia.

title.children: Early childhood education workforce levels 'not sustainable', report finds

image.altText: a man looking sideways while standing outdoors speaking to the media

props.synopsis: The Liberal federal executive launched a takeover of the party's New South Wales division after 140 candidates for the upcoming local government elections failed to be nominated.

title.children: NSW Liberals forced into federal takeover after local election blunder

image.altText: Meningococcal under a microscope

props.synopsis: Queensland Health say the five-month-old boy from Cairns' northern beaches is in a critical but stable condition in hospital.

title.children: Third child in three weeks contracts meningococcal B in 'major' Cairns outbreak

image.altText: An aerial view of a woman wearing a wide-brimmed hat, sitting on the side of a swimming pool while working on her laptop.

props.synopsis: 'Quiet vacationing' is the trend of working from somewhere other than home, without telling your boss. But is it a good idea?

title.children: Taking holidays without telling your boss is trending. But is it a good idea?

image.altText: Gisele P walking into the courthouse with two cameras pointed at her.

props.synopsis: One of the 72-year-old woman's lawyers says she wants all the hearings to be public so that "events like these never happen again".

title.children: French man, 71, accused of drugging his wife, to allow strangers to rape her

image.altText: A photo of NT Attorney-General Selena Uibo at the announcement of the Aboriginal Justice Agreement.

props.synopsis: Selena Uibo has been named the new leader of Territory Labor after the party's landslide defeat in the NT election. It makes her the first Indigenous woman to lead a major political party in Australian history.

title.children: New NT Opposition Leader Selena Uibo becomes first Indigenous woman to lead a major Australian party

image.altText: Two men walk past a military guard

props.synopsis: Living in Russia's shadow, Mongolia is not in a position to put President Vladimir Putin offside. But when he came to visit, the nation's obligations to the International Criminal Court were put into stark relief.

title.children: Vladimir Putin defied a war crimes arrest order to visit Mongolia. Here's what he might be up to

image.altText: A logo on a vehicle reads "Queensland police".

props.synopsis: Police are investigating the sudden death of a one-year-old boy at a daycare centre in Brisbane's east.

title.children: Police investigate sudden death of 1yo boy at daycare centre in Brisbane's east

image.altText: A graphic illustration shows a woman lying in bed staring at her phone in the dark

props.synopsis: We all know the pain of a blaring alarm clock after a late night, but sleep deprivation does more than just bring our mood down. This is what happens when you consistently short change yourself of a good night's rest.

title.children: Are you in the 25 per cent of people not getting enough sleep? Here's what it's doing to your body and brain

image.altText: Hands grasping a cyclone wire fence.

props.synopsis: The 15-year-old has been in state care since he was two days old. He has a "significant" disability but rarely received the care he needed, a magistrate says.

title.children: Indigenous boy imprisoned for two-thirds of this year may not have offended if he'd received proper care from state

image.altText: Fire extinguisher tanks in a firefighters room.

props.synopsis: An ABC investigation has heard from more than a dozen people about allegations of a "macho hero" culture in Queensland's fire service.

title.children: 'Attractive' female firefighting recruits subjected to 'bell ringing' at Brisbane training academy

image.altText: Electronic gaming machines at a gambling venue

props.synopsis: Australians lead the world when it comes to gambling. But the only area of gaming and gambling where we appear to be lacking is in the area of legislation and oversight.

title.children: Why Australia is addicted to gambling

image.altText: A woman sitting at a press conference.

props.synopsis: Nine years after Japanese journalist Shiori Ito was allegedly raped by a powerful man, she has produced a documentary, Black Box Diaries, chronicling her road to justice.

title.children: Police considered Shiori Ito's rape case a 'black box'. She forced Japanese society to look inside

image.altText: An outstretched hand close-up with a gold nugget in the open palm.

props.synopsis: An earth-shaking experiment links the same principles found in your barbecue lighter to the creation of gold nuggets.

title.children: Gold nuggets are often found in quartz — scientists think they now know why
